Ye fair, for whom the hands of Hymen weave</br>The nuptial wreath to deck your virgin brow,</br>While pleasing pains the conscious bosom heave,</br>And on the kindling cheek the blushes glow:
Whose spotless soul contains the better dow'r,</br>Whose life unstain'd full many virtues vouch,</br>For whom now Venus frames the fragrant bow'r,</br>And scatters roses o'er the expecting couch:
To you I sing. — Ah!  ere the raptur'd youth</br>With trembling hand removes the jealous veil,</br>Where, long regardless of the vows of truth,</br>Unsocial coyness stamp'd th' ungrateful seal,
Allow the poet round your flowing hair,</br>Cull'd from an humble vale, a wreath to twine,</br>To Beauty's altar with the Loves repair,</br>And wake the lute beside that living shrine:
That sacred shrine!  where female virtue glows,</br>Where ev'n the Graces all their treasures bring,</br>And where the lily, temper'd with the rose,</br>Harmonious contrast!  breathes an Eden spring:
That shrine!  where Nature with presaging aim,</br>What time her friendly aid Lucina brings,</br>The snowy nectar pours, delightful stream!</br>Where flutt'ring Cupids did their purple wings:
For you who bear a mother's sacred name,</br>Whose cradled offspring, in lamenting strain,</br>With artless eloquence asserts his claim,</br>The boon of nature, but asserts in vain:
Say why, illustrious daughters of the great,</br>Lives not the nursling at your tender breast?</br>By you protected in his frail estate?</br>By you attended, and by you caress'd?
To foreign hands, alas!  can you resign</br>The parent's task, the mother's pleasing care?</br>To foreign hands the smiling babe consign?</br>While Nature starts, and Hymen sheds a tear.
When 'mid the polish'd circle ye rejoice,</br>Or roving join fantastic Pleasure's train,</br>Unheard perchance the nursling lifts his voice,</br>His tears unnotic'd, and unsooth'd his pain.
Ah!  what avails the coral crown'd with gold?</br>In heedless infancy the title vain?</br>The colours gay the purfled scarfs unfold?</br>The splendid nurs'ry, and th' attendant train?
Far better hadst thou first beheld the light,</br>Beneath the rafter of some roof obscure;</br>There in a mother's eye to read delight,</br>And in her cradling arm repose secure.—
Nor wonder, shou'd Hygeia, blissful Queen!</br>Her wonted salutary gifts recall,</br>While haggard Pain applies his dagger keen,</br>And o'er the cradle Death unfolds his pall.
The flow'ret ravish'd from its native air,</br>And bid to flourish in a foreign vale,</br>Does it not oft elude the planter's care,</br>And breathe its dying odors on the gale?
For you, ye plighted fair, when Hymen crowns</br>With tender offspring your unshaken love,</br>Behold them not with rigor's chilling frowns,</br>Nor from your sight unfeelingly remove.
Unsway'd by fashion's dull unseemly jest,</br>Still to the bosom let your infant cling,</br>There banquet oft, an ever-welcome guest,</br>Unblam'd inebriate at that healthful spring.
With fond solicitude each pain assuage,</br>Explain the look, awake the ready smile;</br>Unfeign'd attachment so shall you engage,</br>To crown with gratitude maternal toil:
So shall your daughters in affliction's day,</br>When o'er your form the gloom of age shall spread,</br>With lenient converse chase the hours away,</br>And smooth with duty's hand the widow's bed:
Approach, compassionate, the voice of grief,</br>And whisper patience to the closing ear;</br>From comfort's chalice minister relief,</br>And in the potion drop a filial tear.
So shall your sons, when beauty is no more,</br>When fades the languid lustre in your eye,</br>When Flatt'ry shuns her dulcet notes to pour,</br>The want of beauty, and of praise, supply:

Ev'n from the wreath that decks the warrior's brow</br>Some chosen leaves your peaceful walks shall strew:</br>And ev'n the flow'rs on classic ground that blow,</br>Shall all unfold their choicest sweets for you.
When to th' embattled host the trumpet blows,</br>While at the call fair Albion's gallant train</br>Dare to the field their triple-number'd foes,</br>And chase them speeding o'er the martial plain:
The mother kindles at the glorious thought,</br>And to her son's renown adjoins her name;</br>For, at the nurt'ring breast, the hero caught</br>The love of virtue, and the love of fame.
Or in the senate when Britannia's cause</br>With gen'rous themes inspires the glowing mind,</br>While list'ning freedom grateful looks applause,</br>Pale slav'ry drops her chain, and sculks behind:
With conscious joy the tender parent fraught,</br>Still to her son's renown adjoins her name;</br>For, at the nurt'ring breast, the patriot caught</br>The love of virtue, and the love of fame.</br>
